bibl.title: Letter from Edwin Denby to Howard A. Kelly, August 15, 1907

div1.p: Denby makes a contribution to the fund for Kissinger. As a member of Congress, he offers to introduce a bill in the House of Representatives. Included at the end of the letter is a reply from [Kelly] to Denby, on September 4, 1907, thanking him for his contribution.

div1.head: Letter from Edwin Denby to Howard A. Kelly, August 15, 1907
div1.opener:
acknowledged.
House of Representatives U. S.
Washington, D.C.
Detroit, August 15, 1907.
Dr. L.
Kissinger
Mr. Howard A. Kelly,
1418 Eutaw Place,
Baltimore, Md.
Dear Sir:
div1.p:
Mrs. Henry L. Lyster, of this city, has handed me
your letter to her, dated June 29, and a clipping from The
Outlook in regard to private Kissinger, who offered himself
for experimentation during the investigation of the yellow
fever mosquito and who was taken ill with yellow fever as a
result. Kissinger appears to be now helpless and dependent
upon charity or aid from the Government for his support.

I enclose to you herein my check for five dollars to
be used for this man, and I would like to know whether or not
any arrangements have been made for the introduction of a
special bill in his behalf at the next session of Congress.
If not, I shall be very glad to introduce a bill if Kissinger's
friends wish me to do so. I think that under the circum-
stances surrounding this case whatever of technical defect
there may be in his claim for pension would be waived in
consideration of the splendid courage exhibited in the war
House of Representatives U.S.
Washington, D.C.
H. A. K.-2.
with yellow fever and that Congress would probably allow this
pension. Please let me know whether or not you and the
others interested would care to have me introduce such a bill,
and if so, give me such information as you can concerning
Mr. Kissinger, his company, regiment, etc., etc., together
with the details of his service.

div1.opener:
Sept 4/ 07.
Hon. Edwin Denby,
Detroit, Mich.
Dear Sir,--
div1.p:
Thank you very much for your
kind letter about Kissinger. He is great-
ly in need of help, although for the
immediate present some kind friends like
yourself have provided for him.

I will take up the matter of the bill
when my secretary and literary assistant
come home, and write to you again early
in October.

Please allow me to thank you and ac-
knowledge your check for $ 5-, which
will be forwarded to him shortly.
